review.title: The Computational Complexity of Dominance and Consistency in CP-Nets
review.abstract: We investigate the computational complexity of testing dominance and consistency in CP-nets. Previously, the complexity of dominance has been determined for restricted classes in which the dependency graph of the CP-net is acyclic. However, there are preferences of interest that define cyclic dependency graphs; these are modeled with general CP-nets. In our main results, we show here that both dominance and consistency for general CP-nets are PSPACE-complete. We then consider the concept of strong dominance, dominance equivalence and dominance incomparability, and several notions of optimality, and identify the complexity of the corresponding decision problems. The reductions used in the proofs are from STRIPS planning, and thus reinforce the earlier established connections between both areas.

metadata.title: The Computational Complexity of Dominance and Consistency in CP-Nets

sections.text: So far, the complexity of dominance has been determined for limited classes in which the dependency graph of the CP network is acyclic. However, there are interest preferences that define cyclic dependency diagrams; these are modelled using general CP networks. Here, in our main results, we show that both dominance and consistency are PSPACE-complete for general CP networks. We then look at the concept of strong dominance, dominance equivalence and dominance incomparability, as well as several notions of optimism and identify the complexity of the corresponding decision problems. The reductions used in the evidence stem from STRIPS planning, thus reinforcing the previously established links between the two domains.

sections.heading: 3. Propositional STRIPS Planning
sections.text: In this section, we derive some technical results on propositional STRIPS planning that form the basis of our complexity (sections 4 and 5. We determine the complexity of the planning existential problems for propositional STRIPS planning under constraints of input cases that cause the problem of use in studies of dominance and consistency in GCP networks. Let V be a finite set of variables. A state above V is a complete and consistent set of letters above V, which we often consider to be the conjunction of its members. Thus, a state corresponds to a result defined in a CP network context. Definition 6 (Propositional STRIPS planning) By a propositional STRIPS instance, we mean a tuple < V, α0, ACT >, where V is a finite set of propositional variables.

This is the combination of negative letters of all additional variables.

sections.heading: 4. Dominance
sections.text: The aim of this section is to prove that the GCP-DOMINANCE problem is PSPACE-complete, and that the complexity does not decrease even if we limit the class of input factors to CP networks. We use the results of the propositional STRIPS planning from Section 3 to prove that the general GCPDOMINANCE problem is PSPACE-complete. We then show that the complexity does not change if we consider the input GCP network to be locally consistent and locally complete. The similarities between the dominance testing in CP networks and the propositional STRIPS planning were first presented by Boutilier et al. (1999) a reduction that will be discussed in more detail later by Boutilier et al. (2004a), from the dominance problem to the planning existence problem for a class of propositional STRIPS-ACPS planning specifications consisting of inconsistent measures (actions with individual effects).

sections.heading: 4.1 Dominance for Generalized CP-Nets
sections.text: We will prove that the GCP-DOMINANCE problem is PSPACE-complete by reducing the SE STRIPS PLAN problem that we now know is PSPACE-complete.

sections.heading: 4.2 Dominance in CP-Nets
sections.text: In this section we show that GCP DOMINANCE remains PSPACE-complete under the restriction to locally consistent and locally complete GCP networks, i.e. CP networks. We refer to this restriction of GCP DOMINANCE as CP DOMINANCE. Consistency of a GCP network implies local consistency (Proposition 2). Therefore, the reduction of the proof of Theorem 1 (from ACYCLIC SE STRIPS PLAN to GCP DOMINANCE is limited to consistent GCP networks limited to locally consistent GCP networks. Therefore, the PSPACE hardness of the AKYCLIC SE STRIPS PLAN (Proposition 6) implies that the GCPDOMINANCE consistency is limited to locally consistent GCP networks limited to locally consistent GCP networks, and in fact the PACESPESPESPESPEPACCE membership in the MACCE MACCE is limited to MACCE INSPANCE.

sections.heading: 5. Consistency of GCP-Nets
sections.text: In this section, we show that the GCP-CONSISTENCY problem is PSPACE-complete, using the results of Sections 3 and 4.Theorem 3 GCP-CONSISTENCY is PSPACE-complete, even when confined to GCP networks in subjunctive form. Proof: PSPACE hardness is shown by reduction from ACTION-SET ACYCLICITY. We apply the function S from Section 3.2 followed by M from Section 4.1. These maps show instances of ACTION-SET ACYCLICITY on instances of GCP-CONSISTENCY in subjunctive form. By Lemma 1 (iii) and Lemma 2 (ii), an instance of ACTION-SET ACYCLICITY is in subjunctive form.

sections.heading: 7. Problems Concerning Optimality in GCP-Nets
sections.text: We will present them and examine the complexity of the corresponding decision problems.We will first observe that the dominance-equivalence relationship is in fact a network-dominated equivalence relationship (reflexive, symmetric and transitive).We call the dominance class of a result A strongly dominated relationship (reflexive, symmetric and transitive).The relationship between C induces a strict order relationship (a relationship that is irreflexive and transitive) on the basis of dominance classes.We define the dominance class of a result A in a GCP network C by [α] C.The relationship between C induces a strict order relationship (a relationship that is irreflexive and transitive) on the basis of dominance classes.

sections.heading: 8. Concluding Remarks
sections.text: We have shown that dominance and consistency testing in CP networks are both PSPACE-complete. Also, several related problems related to dominance and optimality in CP networks are PSPACE-complete, too.The repeated use of reductions from planning problems confirms the importance of structural similarity between STRIPS planning and reasoning with CP networks. This suggests that the well-developed field of planning algorithms for STRIPS representations, especially for unbound operators (Brafman & Domshlak, 2003), is useful for implementing algorithms for dominance and consistency in CP networks. Our theories extend to CP networks with non-binary domains, and to extensions and variations of CP networks, such as TCP networks.

referenceMentions.context: However, as argued earlier, for instance by Domshlak and Brafman (2002), acyclic CP-nets are not sufficiently expressive to capture human preferences on even some simple domains.
We refer to Papadimitriou (1994) for details.

Let us recall the definition of a decision problem as presented by Ausiello et al. (1999). A decision problem is a pair P = 〈IP ,YP 〉 where IP is a set of strings (formally, a subset of Σ∗, where Σ is a finite alphabet), The decision problem P = 〈IP ,YP 〉 reads as follows: given a string x ∈ IP , decide whether x ∈ YP .
GCP-nets extend the notion of CP-nets (Boutilier et al., 1999).
Some are discussed for instance by Boutilier et al. (2004a) in Section 6 of their paper.

Under this embedding, the concepts of dominance and consistency we introduced here for GCP-nets generalize the ones considered for CP-nets as defined by Boutilier et al. (2004a). Problems CP-DOMINANCE and CP-CONSISTENCY are defined analogously to Definition 3.

Under this embedding, the concepts of dominance and consistency we introduced here for GCP-nets generalize the ones considered for CP-nets as defined by Boutilier et al. (2004a). Problems CP-DOMINANCE and CP-CONSISTENCY are defined analogously to Definition 3. In the paper we are interested in the complexity of dominance and consistency problems for both GCPnets and CP-nets. Therefore, the matter of the way in which these nets (especially CP-nets, as for GCP-nets there are no alternative proposals) are represented is important. Our representation of CP-nets is often more compact than the one proposed by Boutilier et al. (2004a), as the formulas p+(x) and p−(x) implied by the conditional preference tables can often be given equivalent, but exponentially smaller, disjunctive normal form representations.
We have the following result due to Bylander (1994).
This restriction has no effect on the complexity of the plan existence problem: it remains PSPACE-complete under the goal-completeness restriction (Lang, 2004).

PSPACE-completeness of propositional STRIPS planning with single-effect actions was proved already by Bylander (1994). However, to deal with acyclicity we need to give a different reduction than the one used in that paper.

The similarities between dominance testing in CP-nets and propositional STRIPS planning were first noted by Boutilier et al. (1999). They presented a reduction, discussed later in more detail by Boutilier et al.

The similarities between dominance testing in CP-nets and propositional STRIPS planning were first noted by Boutilier et al. (1999). They presented a reduction, discussed later in more detail by Boutilier et al. (2004a), from the dominance problem to the plan existence problem for a class of propositional STRIPS planning specifications consisting of unary actions (actions with single effects).

The similarities between dominance testing in CP-nets and propositional STRIPS planning were first noted by Boutilier et al. (1999). They presented a reduction, discussed later in more detail by Boutilier et al. (2004a), from the dominance problem to the plan existence problem for a class of propositional STRIPS planning specifications consisting of unary actions (actions with single effects). We prove our results for the GCP-DOMINANCE and GCP-CONSISTENCY problems by constructing a reduction in the other direction. This reduction is much more complex than the one used by Boutilier et al. (1999), due to the fact that CP-nets impose more restrictions than STRIPS planning.

Theorem 1 implies the PSPACE-completeness of dominance in the more general conditional preference language introduced by Wilson (2004b), where the conditional preference rules are written in conjunctive form.

metadata.abstractText: We investigate the computational complexity of testing dominance and consistency in CP-nets. Previously, the complexity of dominance has been determined for restricted classes in which the dependency graph of the CP-net is acyclic. However, there are preferences of interest that define cyclic dependency graphs; these are modeled with general CP-nets. In our main results, we show here that both dominance and consistency for general CP-nets are PSPACE-complete. We then consider the concept of strong dominance, dominance equivalence and dominance incomparability, and several notions of optimality, and identify the complexity of the corresponding decision problems. The reductions used in the proofs are from STRIPS planning, and thus reinforce the earlier established connections between both areas.
